H_oJ-vz0-_5eRj3k-Zk4nw.text: This place provides a unique venue for enjoying a British classic.The majority of the seating consists of community style picnic tables under umbrellas outside the storefront.  We had a great time enjoying our meal and chatting with another foreign visiter.  There are several fish options to choose from but I stuck with the classic and shared a large order of the cod fish and chips to share with my boyfriend.  The fish was definitely the star.  The batter was neither too thick or too sparse.  It was delightfully crispy, well seasoned and the fish was moist.  The chips were pretty standard and I wasn't overly impressed by them.  The condiments included tartar sauce, lemon, vinegar and ketchup.  The meal is not cheap (16 pounds for a large order), but sharing worked out well because we supplemented with a beer and neither of us wanted to consume too a large quantity of fried food in one sitting!

CN0vKj5RoSmULNoNdq7c9A.text: We ate here Twice. Fresh and great flavor!  Would recommend!!!

JC9Ocz83zNa2oPfZukAzzw.text: I go for the fried sausage, which was very good! That alone gets a four-star rating.  The location is convenient but it can be hard to get seating when it is crowded.  The fish is average-to-good, the chips average.

n2vySBCLPsDsNjBUgo-Odw.text: Good, but overpriced. Cod was very good, but the 2 pieces had stuck together during cooking, resulting in an uneven level of done-ness. Batter was thicker than Poppie's but was mostly crispy except where the 2 pieces had stuck together. Chips needed to be crispier.

l-yz_N1EcRDz7ZPQunzLaQ.text: I am not a big fan of fish and chips but this is the best place to have fish and chips in London. You will never be let down, you will get what you expect from fish and chips. It's walking distance to everywhere in central, it doesn't always have a table but if you wait you will get one. Highly recommended

6rYK1mykjTe5ayrw2Hm3nw.text: Outstanding fried fish made-to-order. Delicious...and I'm not even a fish and chips fan. Crispy fried batter on the outside, with a fresh and moist piece of cod on the inside. They offer a nice variety of fish on their menu...from halibut to types of fish I've never even heard of. Onto the chips ... not that great. They were a bit cold and seemed like they were sitting out for a while.  And note that fish and chips here don't come cheap...about 13 pounds a plate (although the plate is very large).  Prices for takeout are cheaper than dining in. It's an order-at-the-counter type restaurant without much service and its really crowded, stuffy, and oily smelling inside anyways, so I'd recommend just ordering take away and eating it somewhere on a bench outside...weather pending of course.

h0Bz5v_3UgTD0s3opgJzSQ.text: Tasteless fish.  If it weren't for the tartar sauce it would be borderline non-edible.  All fish served with skin on...if fish skin is your thing.  Chips were chewy and probably sat around for an hour or so before they hit the table.  Service was practically non-existent.  I'd give zero stars if I could.

photos.caption: Photo of Rock & Sole Plaice - London, United Kingdom. Soggy.

c5_vaOZ8Rd8DWYlZNbZN6A.text: We sat outside on their little patio, with strangers on a date...I get the sharing a table thing, I do- limited space, communal atmosphere, sure. But they were sitting on one side of a table, and we were seated on the other, so it was really incredibly awkward. They have a few fried cheese, vegetarian options, but I just had chips and mushy peas, and my mom had the classic fish and chips.  She said it was good, light and crispy and good quality fish. We also ordered dessert- the toffee pudding... and it was really disappointing. Definitely not fresh, pretty dry and sad. Service was fine, if super inattentive (Insert diatribe: service stereotypes about English waiters being inattentive, aloof and sometimes rude are unfair- I find this to be true about LONDON service only.  Having a chance to travel outside of London a bit, I found service everywhere else to be very friendly and of high quality. Crappy service isn't excusable as a cultural idiosyncrasy, in my opinion.)Overall, it was fine, but I don't think it was worth the high prices.  The super central location is probably more the reason for the expense than the quality, as it seems like there are some other, very well reviewed, classic places that are a bit more affordable.

QZ3R3MPYqKVqL874zsagOg.text: I was lucky enough to visit Jolly ol' London during Christmas week of 2011. I took in the sights, and felt my London bid would be incomplete If I didn't try fish and chips. Not knowing jack about London went on Yelp to rely on some good references. I first went to North Sea Seafood Restaurant which was closer to my hotel, but It was closed both days I attempted to go there - which I was kinda pissed. Enter Yelp again and found Rock and Sole Plaice to be my go-to. When I rolled up the table seating outside was jammed, but there was no line to go inside. I walked in and was immediately seated to the only empty table. MENUI peeked at the menu and they had different fish to fry up. I just decided to go traditionally with cod. EATING OPINION10 minutes after ordering my plate comes out heaping with chips and a huge piece of cod. The batter is crispy. Could not taste any beer in the batter. The cod itself when you cut into it is about 1 inch thick. Its soft and fluffy, not rubbery. The chips are crispy, but looked familiar to what we call in the USA - steak fries. There was no skin on the fries so I think these were just a bag of frozen steak fries flash fried. The best part was the tartar sauce on the table. Open the metal lid to reveal this white saucy goodness with seemingly fresh dill. The dill is not strong, but very evident. This tartar sauce really enhances the fish.  Washed it all down with a can of Coke. And yes, the Coke formula in the UK tastes different than the USA. In the end I struggled, but did manage to finish the entire plate cause it was alot of food....but also alot of grease. PRICE/OBSERVATIONSWhile the dish was plentiful it did cost 13.50 pounds for the plate. In comparison, the next day had another random fish and chips run which cost 7.50 for fish and chips. While R&S is very expensive, the serving portion is only slightly larger. I ate at O'Neills Irish Pub with real Irish food. O'Neills is not a fish and chips place, but a pub, so advantage R&S naturally. The fish execution was better at R&S.OVERALLIn all, the dish of fish and chips is a traditional English staple. To me the attraction to most is the simplicity of it. To me, the drawback is the simplicity of it. I like to compare it to chicken tenders or chicken cutlets. While good, I've never eaten a chicken cutlet (batter fried chicken breast strips), or in this case batter fried cod that knocked my socks off. Just good, but not absolute can't miss. Still with that, if I ever came back, I'd try the other fish selections at R&S. I'd recommend R&S for people to try fish and chips, but at 13.50 pounds.

rgnGxXUWnrx8YR3y2CqWzA.text: Damn, I DON'T EVEN LIKE FISH, and I like the fish n chips here!!if you want to eat inside, don't forget there's basement seating that is much larger than the small dining room on ground level

CX72r_oos_S1EW04GI7pGA.text: I grew up less than a stone's throw away from the sea and an even shorter distance from the best fish and chip shop in Kent so when I'm came to London I thought my days of decent fish and chips were probably gone for good.  Fortunately on the advice of a friend I sought out Rock and Soul, hidden amongst the back streets of Covet Garden and after biting into that battered haddock I could almost smell the sea-salt once more.For anyone sick of chicken shops and kebabs this is a reminder of the great British takeaway at its best.  Rock and Sole offer a range of battered fish including, not surprisingly, rock, sole and plaice alongside staples favourites like haddock, cod and scampi as wells as battered sausages, saveloys and the like.  The chips themselves are hand cut and absolutely delicious.You can opt to eat in or takeaway but be warned you will be charged extra to sit on their benches outside.  This 'Plaice' would have got 5 stars had it not been for the extortionate prices they charge.  For a large haddock and chips I had to fork out £8 and had I opted to sit-in it would have been a further £1.50.  I know this is London but this is taking the piss a little.

photos.caption: Photo of Rock & Sole Plaice - London, United Kingdom

K_S7XvDRldmLVYI_cQY8bQ.text: This really is a real old fashioned style fish and chip shop stuck right in the centre of town on Endell Street on the north side of Covent Garden. If you find yourself in London and fancying fish and chips - find this place it is the real deal.It is abit pricey but hey you are in the centre of tourism land. The rock and chips will cost you 6.00 to take out. It is good though and since you will pay this sort of money pretty much where ever you take out, I suppose it is worth it.You get the good old fashioned wrapped up take out to enjoy on one of the benches in the street if you can find an empty one.

photos.caption: Photo of Rock & Sole Plaice - London, United Kingdom

Jzpk7tb8me45WfF3Rb6E9g.text: Expensive tourist trap with bad food and service to match.

Qz9ggpM1SSV3-WF_V6Y4Bw.text: We heard good things from our longtime London native friend, so being in the area one evening we hit this very small chippie for a quick meal.  The outdoor patio and ground floor were packed, so we descended into the basement eating area which, like many a london resto-cave, tends to be cold and reverberating. However, there are some pretty awesome murals of undersea creatures to keep you company.At first glance, the prices kind of knocked us back, especially with the overall feel of the place screaming middle of the road; but our waiter, sensing our trepidation, did a very good job of instilling confidence in us.  When our plates came, it was a giant fillet of absolutely delectable perfectly cooked Cod, crispy and tasty but not oily batter, and large wedge handcut chips that oozed buttery potato on every bite, slopped in homemade ketchup and tartar.  We changed our minds about the value--worth it--, but our waiter was not done trying to make sure we left satisfied, and threw in some sponge cake desserts that complimented the meal perfectly.  Can't say this is standard operating procedure, but rest assured we rolled out of there proclaiming this little chippie the Central London Master.

ejkMnh_lHVwqu2e7svLZYg.text: Coming from the USA, I was looking for a good fish and chip.   This place did the trick but it was not great.

xuB8Oqxzz1jjbyTcjSMzNg.text: Want fish and chips in london - this is your plaice :D,  along with a spot of London history (the menu has all the details)I'm personally just a fan of the fat chips (vegie options are not the best), but my friends and family tell me the fish is pretty good.It gets v busy so be prepared to wait for a table, although if you've had your fill of people watching, they have a good downstairs area (you just need to go behind the counter to get to it)

5iVH4nBrGEsnfzMXzn3Nxg.text: Being this the first trip to the UK for my companion, I was delighted to hear she oblidge me in visiting a proper English chippie during our short stay. The trusty Yelp app recommended Rock & Sole and after shopping in Covent Garden off we went.The location is convenient, and the menu easy. We arrived just before peak lunch and were able to find a cozy spot to sit. The small space of no more than a dozen seats was quickly flooded with take-away patrons and those that were dining in squeezed into every seat, including the extra at our table. For if the space had been larger, I would not have been treated to learning the customer sitting next to me was having a falling out with her flatmate. Entertainment +1 The biggest dissapointment was what seems to be a pattern. When asking for Haddock, we were informed only Cod was available fresh. We asked again for the Haddock , willing to wait, and were fairly pushed into choosing the Cod as it was "just fried". We opted to go with the Cod save for waiting an indeterminate amount of time. Unfortunately we waited 15 minutes anyway for that fresh cod. Thankfully the portions are large and filling and as good as I remember it.

e99H96tKFMKbY2uKIGiGdQ.text: A British-American friend who went on an excursion a couple of years back to find the best fish and chipstold me this was the place. So off we went...Their logo resembles that of Bubba Gump's (not a good sign). The interior looks like any corner pizza joint in NY. Was I at the right place? "Don't judge a book by it's cover" rings true. The food was very good. The tartar sauce tasted like it was made fresh daily. The chips were okay. The fish is served skin on--a first for me. That batter was crunchy the food was hot. But $53 for this meal (two people) seemed a bit steep.

G5B_DN25rH8PdE-p7umVLg.text: I'll admit it, I lived in London for over a year and had never tried proper fish and chips.  On my most recent visit, I dragged a friend into Rock and Sole to try it out.  We were fortunate to find an indoor seat, but it became ridiculously crowded after we snagged the last table.  After ordering our beverages we waited ten minutes before asking another server to bring us some tap water.  I can understand that they were busy, but the other tables seemed to get their beverages without issue.We split a "large" cod and it was too much for us to share.  The fish was absolutely fantastic, it was the perfect level of crispiness.  The tartar sauce was top notch and really enhanced the fish.  My friend assured me that the chips were mediocre and reminded me that there were plenty of better chippys near her flat.I wouldn't necessarily suggest eating in.  The prices are significantly higher to eat-in, so taking away may be a better option.  Yes, I'm a tourist so I'm biased, but this was a great choice and I'd suggest grabbing a bite here.

5HZ1456Uyu7NfMNC4WBCSw.text: ** Overall Score: 3.38 (B+)** Verdict: Quality fish and chips, but too pricey.[FOOD]* Deliciousness: A-. I ordered a Large Haddock with chips for takeaway (£11). The haddock was good, and the batter was just nice -- neither too thick nor too thin. It could have been a little softer though. The chips were lightly salted and came in varying sizes; they were crispy on the outside and fluffy on the inside -- great!* Freshness/Cleanliness: B+. The haddock tasted fresh, but it could have been previously frozen. No complaints otherwise.[SERVICE]* Friendliness: B+.* Time to Order: A. Considering that I visited duing lunch time (1pm) and they were out of large haddock when I placed my order, I only had to wait two or three minutes before my order was ready. Quite speedy![VALUE]* Portion Size: A. Huge portions; coupled with chips, a large fish would be too much for one person. Better for sharing.* Prices: C. The outstanding reputation of this store might have inflated its prices somewhat, but they are still too high, even when the good quality of the fish and chips is taken into consideration. A large order of fish and chips cost £11, while dine-in costs £14. To make matters worse, no mayonnaise or tartar sauce is provided for takeout orders -- how can one eat fish and chips without that?{Scoring Guide: A - Outstanding; B - Average; C - Below Average; D - Terrible}

YsJ5mp8CBIaihrlbdtMItw.text: The food was good, but nothing to write home about. There are too many great places in London to waste your time and money here. I wish that I would have known take away was £5 cheaper before I sat down and ordered. I didn't even have my own table. My wife and I had to share a table with another couple. Also the service wasn't that great. The servers mumbled, were short,  and somewhat cold. They seemed annoyed with our being there. A smile or a thank you would have been nice. It felt odd because in contrast with the rest of Europe, Londoners are typically the warmest and most welcoming.I advise you move along.

tzv6wPm-VXRdLyhsIVmLqg.text: Definitely a solid, no-frills chippy in Covent Garden.  As I'm a tourist I can't say definitively that it was overpriced, but maybe it's normal given the neighborhood and proximity to all the theaters.I had the haddock which was excellent, and the cole slaw which was also excellent.  Don't waste your money on the onion rings.

YtKepzWbvoyZGKlzZU41Bw.text: Love the Rock and Sole in Coventry Garden. Always make a point to come for fish and chips when passing through London. Great outdoor picnic seating but beware of the pigeons! Still worth it!!

photos.caption: Photo of Rock & Sole Plaice - London, United Kingdom

Q5UdNfv1Jh4Fc6PL8WaTfQ.text: This is my first Fish and Chips experience in the UK. I had the fried Cod and Haddock and both were very good. My favorite dish was the King Prawns! The seafood were good however the chips could be more crispy as they are really thick and just lightly fried. If you walk in and see a packed place don't worry there are more seats downstairs.

zMSEM8oWf_7DotL-TljcIA.text: I have gotten take away here a couple of times and I love that there is never any wait time. They literally just give you your food right when you order it. I get the cod and it is delicious and perfectly fried. However, the chips are just okay and sometimes you get a few stale ones. Make sure you ask for salt, vinegar, and tartar sauce (& sometimes they charge you for tartar sauce). It is a little over-priced but the portions are very large so you won't be hungry after a meal here. There are better places to eat in London but if you are looking for traditional fish & chips or a quick and simple meal, this is the place to come!

2i97HXv-J9dH7zuWMFx3pw.text: Full disclosure: I'm a tourist from the United States.Dinner was a disappointment, given what I'd read from other reviewers.The chips were average at best. The fish was pretty decent, juicy inside and crispy outside, but nothing to write home about. On quality of the food alone, I'd give them 3/5 stars.But what brings them down to 2/5 stars is the value. A large, single fillet of cod, a couple handfuls of chips, and a beer was 22 pounds. It wouldn't have been worth 22 dollars, let alone the exchange rate. Yesterday I stumbled across a different Fish & Chips restaurant near the river and paid about 15-18 pounds (can't remember exactly because the price was reasonable enough so as to be forgettable) for the same amount of fish and chips and beer, and yet it came with a side of peas, to boot.All in all, not the best way I've spent my money this trip. It probably didn't help that the waitress shorted me a pound when she brought me the change for my tab.

SJWJIqGhgn8_blAGnz64ow.text: I came to the Rock and Sole Place after reading the reviews in here, ordered the haddock fish and chips. I must say that the portions are huge, although I was very hungry, the meal was indeed filling. The food was excellent, the chips were home style fat fries which i would rate as 8 out of 10. The staff was nice and service was relatively quick. I am very pleased with the overall experience and would indeed recommend this place to friends.

2SBvTdFTEPx8r60zgJzQbA.text: I enjoyed my food here more than 3 stars might suggest, but end up feeling that London has enough food offerings that the two main drawbacks of Rock and Sole added up.First, the good.  The fish and chips were delicious.  The cod tasted fresh, the batter was delicious, and the whole thing crisped up beautifully.  The portion was generous, as well.  The same went for the fries--nice and chunky, offered in great quantity.  I also liked the little cup of dipping sauce.  Something dill-filled.  So the good is the food.The drawbacks--pretty much non-existent service and high prices.  The meal was great, but when I think about how much it cost, it feels disjointed.  The prices would be more appropriate for a fancy dinner.  As for the service, our waitress didn't check in on us once (among other problems, this resulted in us needing but never getting water refills), and the two questions I had for her received only mumbles as a reply.  It's possible that she wasn't comfortable with the language.We sat outside under the big umbrellas.  It was in no way private or intimate, but the setting was still nice.I would happily send friends here, but I'd let them know that they are going only for the food, and they'll be paying a LOT for it.

y0FA4__oun5un88BrDtKTQ.text: i have found- i Do not like British food. Tastes pretty bland for me.. and i'm asian. there are Lots of fish to choose frompretty ExpensiveFastCooked wellJust didn't like the flavors, but my dining partner and new husband quite liked it.

qWLf8894bbfMdrTCQIuTcA.text: With so many fish and chip joints how the hell did we pick?  Well, I definitely consulted Yelp that's for sure.  As it turns out, our schedule, in part, dictated our options.  The place we most wanted to hit was just too far from us and we were packing in a lot on our short trip.  Other possibilities closed too early.So one evening we found ourselves here.  Knowing this place has been around since the late-1800s boded well.  Seeing the storefront didn't.  There's not much by way of ambiance.  There's some indoor seating in this small restaurant and more picnic-style seating outside.  There's table service if you're dining in, otherwise order at the counter for take-away.We sat inside, placed our orders and our food came out pretty quickly.  They offer various kinds of fish (cod, haddock, plaice, rock, skate, halibut and lemon sole).  I had the COD and my friend had the HADDOCK.  You can order a regular or large.  The regular fish was huge!  The breading was fantastic, crunchy and not very greasy at all.  And the plate was heaping with thick-cut crispy chips.  There's plenty of malt vinegar, but they don't give you much lemon.  You also only get a tiny container of their tartar sauce...their amazing tartar sauce.  I had added a side of MUSHY PEAS but it never came out so I cancelled it.  Otherwise, a great meal.After catching a show on our last night, we were both hungry as we left the theatre and could not have been more on the same page.  What better farewell meal than fish and chips?!  So we came back.  The thing is, there are no guarantees when you come here near closing time.  There was still half an hour left but we saw they were shutting down the outdoor tables.  When we walked in, one of the servers had to check to see if we could still order something.  We were told we could do take-away.  The guy behind the counter grabbed the fish from a heated compartment and tossed them into take-away containers along with chips.  Take-away is cheaper than eating in, but tartar sauce costs extra (50 pence).We walked outside and seriously grubbed.  Even after sitting under some heated lamp, the fish was still great!

jIKER3MsUZp_ZWFuX0pSsQ.text: I ordered the Cod & Chips with salt and vinegar to go. I highly recommend getting the vinegar on your portion. If vinegar has an absolute purpose, then it may be being generously applied to Rock & Sole Plaice's Cod & Chips. The Cod crust was perfectly crisp. The fish itself was fresh which you can tell by the taste and the gray skin (If wrong, I've absolutely failed to learn anything as a native Islander). From now on, the fish and chips here are the standard to which I compare all other future fish and chips to.As you can tell, I was absolutely impressed by the food; however, the price was another story. A regular portion to take-away was 10, and to sit in cost over 50% more, so I decided to take-away and find a cozy spot in Covent Garden to munch in. The food may have been worthy of five stars, but the price to dine-in and the accommodations restrain Rock & Sole.To summarize, great takeaway spot. If you want a proper Fish & Chips experience in which you sit down at a cozy, low-arching pub and grab a pint of a cask ale, then I recommend the Windsor Castle in Notting Hill.

PvVyZDse1QhAzvf8SEU1vg.text: We were on a quest to find the best fish and chips in central London. This place did not make our list. Maybe it was because we came so late - 30 minutes before close, we had to sit inside as they had just closed the outside seating area. In any case, we left quite disappointed. We both ordered the the regular cod. The fish was fine, but greasy and the chips were hot, but very hard (had to pick through them to find edible pieces). Seemed to be old chips that had been sitting under a heating lamp for too long. In any case, very disappointing. Note: getting to the downstairs bathrooms are a bit treacherous in heels, so be careful!

photos.caption: Photo of Rock & Sole Plaice - London, United Kingdom. Regular cod with chips. Chips were very hard - maybe old and under heater too long.
Photo of Rock & Sole Plaice - London, United Kingdom. Interior.

fJSmXt-E-H0qxTSTf-9RUg.text: Rock & Sole is alright, I suppose... it was highly recommended by my coworkers, but why is it so expensive? It's about £14 just for the regular sized piece of cod, which I just don't think is worth it. Call me cheap, but I didn't think it tasted doubly better than other pubs I've been to where the fish & chips are half the price. The chips also came out soggy, which I did not like. The tartar sauce was pretty delicious, but the sauce is supposed to compliment the fish, not the other way around.I left feeling a bit unsatisfied, but overall the quality of the food is okay... nothing to rave about.

kY8mNF1S9OonaFVYYqZYgQ.text: A few friends living in London said this was their favorite spot to get Fish and Chips that is NOT from a pub, and I would agree. The quality of the Cod was the best I had enjoyed on the entire 10 day trip, having Fish and Chips multiple times during the stay. Very good, and some sweet and spicy curry sauce on the side was a nice kick for the fries! Very good experience overall

photos.caption: Photo of Rock & Sole Plaice - London, United Kingdom. Curry sauce (for fries or whatever you fancy)
Photo of Rock & Sole Plaice - London, United Kingdom. Cod and Chips, reg size

pf3bNfyUvIaVt3x-gXEKVA.text: Every tourist visiting London wants to try Fish and Chips, the most famous-- but not national--dish of the U.K. Unfortunately many of these tourists will end up settling for a substandard frozen then refried, saltless, tasteless rendition of this dish, at the chain of Taylor Walker pubs dotted throughout the tourist-heavy areas of London. This was the mistake I made in my first day here, and came away unsurprised, believing the myth of British food being mediocre to be true.Then I discovered The Rock and Plaice. Tucked away in the popular Covent Garden area, Rock and Plaice is easily accessible by train. The outdoor seating area is prime, if you're lucky enough to have the notorious London weather cooperating. Inside, the restraunt has a homey vibe; an open kitchen greets you with the warm smell of frying fish and chips (fries for my fellow Americans). The basement has additional seating and a somehow well-placed Jamaican vibe. Now to the food. I ordered the standard fried cod and chips. Fried layer on the fish was excellent, as if it had been hand breaded and dongle fried. The tartar was essential for giving the fish extra flavor and the chips were crisped to perfection. I feel the British have a predilection for sugar over salt, and I felt both items could have used a bit more sodium chloride, but none the less if you're from out of town and proper fish and chips, this plaice is rock solid.

photos.caption: Photo of Rock & Sole Plaice - London, United Kingdom

bATPJ2L8s4PIDuqVkIRiBw.text: This place was the best Fish & Chips I found in London.I tried The Halibut excellent., The Haddock excellent, and The Cod excellent.The chips were good, though not my favorite.The mushy peas were tasty too!!!It's tricky to get a table outside it gets super packed.Hey you might get to sit with total strangers and meet some new friends when it is super packed.In the summer time it is super hot inside.

photos.caption: Photo of Rock & Sole Plaice - London, United Kingdom

6pmAc10lm43rm81UQe6RUA.text: Had a large haddock with chips, take away, at £11.5, which is £5 cheaper thanks to Yelp reviews stating so. The fish was absolutely delicious. It remained crispy despite the 15 minutes journey back and was seasoned only with salt and vinegar. Chips were more like wedges than skinny fries and were filled with potato. Overall, awesome flavour and since we got the larger sized one, it was enough to share between 2 persons. It's a must try!

uY5fjaxx6J1myb4OeQfYxw.text: Genuine fish and chips in London. You may end up sharing a table with some locals here (and tourists) but it's definitely worth stopping by.I got the cod and chips. The cod is quite large. What really makes it stand out is the tartar sauce. The chips were only okay but it's hard to make them that different or outstanding. The mash peas were supposed to be housemade but weren't in fact (confessed the waiter) -- they were okay.

vq6RAQmgwrJzmPnPoE0rKw.text: The good: These are very good chip shop chips. The haddock however, is cooked perfectly in a wonderfully crispy batter.   The bad: Chip shop chips are really awful; hasn't anyone that has ever owned a chip shop heard of the twice fry method? The mushy peas taste of disinfectant.  For what you're getting, this place is stupid expensive.I am surrounded by tourists who are eating what they think is a popular British dish and in a dozen or more languages I can hear them say that the people in this country obviously have no taste.The best thing about this place is a smiley waitress that pleasantly fills out her T-Shirt.  Really, if you like fish and chips go somewhere else and eat the same food for half the price. If you are a tourist trying to experience British take-away food, go to a curry house.

photos.caption: Photo of Rock & Sole Plaice - London, United Kingdom. Haddock, chips, mushy peas and the only cola in the world.

BzzBQr2cfO3SicE-WH2vsA.text: Went here after high recommendation but was think this place is okay. Fish is good but not better then something closer. Service was bad as well.

IM0WZyGXmIMWi54IoApLgQ.text: So as a tourist I went hunting for the best fish and chips and this place came up in my cousin's TAIWANESE tour book. Apparently everyone else dining that day had the same tour book because everyone was either Japanese or Taiwanese, but I did see a few Brits going in for takeaway orders - ANYWAY - Get the cod, like you're supposed to when you eat Fish and Chips and you honestly can't go wrong. Best fish and chips EVER - that is exactly how it is supposed to be. And I love the condiment tray they provide, with the tartar sauce and the dill - didn't get that anywhere else. And the chips are damn good as well! I kind of still think about it.

CTF9aVD0Jupr-2V2lQixDg.text: Obviously with such a playfully nautical name, proper batter fried fish is to be expected. I've yet to be disappointed. Luring throngs of tourists, late night drunkards and seemingly everybody else not on a diet (we've seen suit-and-tied business meetings going on in here), Rock and Sole Plaice is a satisfactory choice for when that chippy craving hits. Yes, their chips (londonist.com/2010/02/lo…) are excellent. I tend to spend a considerable amount of time at the Hospital Club (qype.co.uk/place/111188-…) . it's awfully tempting knowing this place is just across the street. With my brother and his wife coming into town from the States, I'll a good excuse this month to indulge! Yep, it's a no-brainer destination for tourists.

1x-4_RIrdPp9LxoZ5fVzAg.text: i've been coming here for fish & chips for the past ten years or so. the fish has gone a little downhill and the portions seem to have shrunk, but i can't bring myself to try any other fish & chip restaurants. their tartar sauce is sooo yummy and the cod is delicious.it's a great place to have a lunch or early dinner after a day of walking around covent garden. i enjoy the outdoor seating, though the pigeons can sometimes be an issue. service is very prompt when seated upstairs. i sat in the downstairs area for the first time this past winter and did not like it! service was much, much slower (or at least that particular night) and i didn't like the feeling of eating in a basement. there used to be this really creepy asian man that worked there, so it is bittersweet to see that he's not working there anymore. he always added some amusement to my dinners here...all in all, a good (albeit a lil pricy) fish & chips restaurant in a nice location. service is fast, food tastes good, and there's usually no wait for a table.

omSdzzmU-03FVlAdmp1ebA.text: I used to be a huge fan of this place.  The fish and chips were always hot, freshly made, and oh-so-tasty. But I went back a few weeks ago and was served a portion of cod and chips that was NOT freshly fried, and it was downright disgusting.  Dry fish, greasy fried batter, NOT nice.  I think the key is coming when it's busy (strangely enough) so that you are guaranteed a freshly friend portion.  If you come during a downtime, you might get a nasty pre-fried fish, and then it's just bad bad news.

-UZ7i1twMINSDwPGmiw9nQ.text: my dad's british, and was stuck on some ghetto/old place that he'd always claimed to be the best fish and chips in London- after one experience here, he liked this better.fish and chips is simple right? but restaurants try to go crazy, diversifying their menu/portfolio with a bunch of random semi-good items. here they just stick to fish & chips. this why this place does it so well. it's just simply, well thought out. it's just a couple of guys, you point to the type of fish you want (or you know, you could speak too), they fry up the fish, add a side, and give it to you as you sit on a shady/awkwardly placed table.perfect description: cheap and cheerful.it's an awesome place to stop by if you're hanging/shoppin in the area too.

84MNAKFPqygeoqcoPnEmew.text: This may be a restaurant for tourists, but I had a satisfying meal of fish and chips. This corner shop reminds me of Guy Fieri and his show DDD...the fish was big and the chips were plenty. I liked what I saw on the menu - a variety of fish, not just the ol' boring cod. I ordered halibut. The batter was crispy and light, and the fish was nice and meaty. Their homemade tartar sauce was tasty, I used all of it and wanted more. Sure you're not going to get excellent service from this place, but that was okay with me because I didn't expect much. It was a wonderful fish & chip experience I had in London.

IUh_nRkEJNy98ivmk5I3PQ.text: Pretty rock solid chippy here. Very convenient location, clean facility and incredibly friendly and funny staff. Haddock, cod and mushy peas were all excellent, for a mere 32 GBP for two.

4_R4MwxqS8ahDmh-y5BQiw.text: These were the biggest calamari that we have ever seen. Great flavor and tender!  Huge portions, certainly you can share a plate. Served quick. Nice location.

qsa0vurkCj3XpHCHwDgqQw.text: Hands down, best fish and chips in London!!!!  And for you travelers from the U.S. out there, finding fish and chips in London is darn near impossible!!!!  Every time I go to London I have to stop in here for fish and chips because they are so good!

xtRK38_-rARGVt7crrKnsA.text: The best proper fish and chips.  There are over a dozen types of fish to choose from.  It is fried properly and the chips are real potatoes and steak fry size.  This is the must go to place for fish and chips.  I also had a serving of mushy peas which were perfect.  I witnessed a fews guys just getting chips and gravy if that's any indication of the value and taste of the chips.

o03Q0O8UhyNSkHkGla1Mtg.text: The best fish and chips EVER!!  I ordered the regular sole and it was so moist, tender, and nicely seasoned.  The batter was nice and crunchy and so were the chips, not heavy or oily at all.  I loved the big and crunchy  pieces/chunks of chips, they were just amazing with the tartar sauce.  I would suggest to get a regular order instead of a large order, it was just enough food for me.  Ultimately, the best fish and chips I've ever had!

DDV2YNqYkJOFTThH-4FxwQ.text: Classic fish and chips, some outdoor seating, friendly, efficient service. We went back again.

Bg2XzU5qPQgPZ-Z1QyyCeg.text: Expensive- especially if you eat in! Takeaway is substantially cheaper. But they do such good chips! Really good sized portions and good chip shop chips- chunky and thick with a fantastic flavour. The mushy peas here are great too. The fish is fantastic, cooked to perfection and crispy light batter. Smother them in salt and vinegar and I'm in heaven!

ZVaAWz0uAemyWMDq1i6KiA.text: I suppose when a restaurant can rely upon a steady flow of customers because of its reputation and cult status the management can afford to be a little arrogant and prescriptive. For some reason I wasn't allowed to order just a plate of chips today (despite it being an option on the menu), but was prompted to order something else to go with the chips. When I said that I didn't want anything else (I'm a vegetarian and didn't feel like battered camembert) it was clear that I was expected to leave. And so I did.

VnCSA6h62tiKTkxrze8-1Q.text: evisted The Rock and Sole Plaice yesterday after an adsence of a couple of years . The fish was awful and not cooked to order as were the chips both had been hanging around for a considerable period of time. Batter was poor and I suspect the cod was not cod either. This place has gone to the dogs I'm afraid.

YYCxGBon6r0PNZLIbh3VTw.text: The oldest fish and chip shop in London - from 1871! - and declared by many to be the best. It is very pretty for a fish and chip shop, the outside covered in a mural (you can get a free postcard of it too!) and hanging baskets of climbing plants. Coloured lights hang outside it over picnic tables, and it's nice to sit outside because there isn't too much traffic in Endell Street, especially in the evenings. The beautiful smell of vinegar over chips lures you inside. The food is very traditional - battered fish (and please don't eat cod, it is nearly extinct!), pickled onions, sausages, and big, fat, perfectly cooked chips in paper. I lived round the corner as a child and I used to stare at the bright white hair and eyebrows of the men of the family who run it while I waited on tiptoe for my chips. Oh, and they have nice wooden chip forks.

PUTJPB5wzAoodKiZEZnADQ.text: I can't count how many times somebody has recommended this place to me and I've often walked past and smelt the alluring aroma of vinegary chips. So I decided at last to cave in to temptation and give it a go. I ordered cod and chips and to be honest I wasn't bowled over by their offering. That's not to say the food wasn't above average - the chips were chunky and cooked well, the fish tasty (although the batter was a bit heavy) - but at 10 pounds a pop to eat-in, it was pretty pricey.

xRzyeB_wfQlFdsMb1TTArg.text: A reliable chippy. We take all our tourist friends here.

usURrNO0H5DIIvMnspUp6g.text: ok, i was taking my first trip to London, and i only had about 2 days to spend there, and at my bf's bar in san diego there were some Brits hanging out, doing some rock band kereoke, and i posed this question to them: " the only thing i want to make SURE i do there is have some bomb fish and chips.  where do they have the best fish and chips in London?" and right away he responded, "The Rock and Sole Plaice."i am SO glad he told me about this place.  Covent Garden is basically like a MAZE and while looking for The Rock and Sole Plaice i basically just got lucky and stumbled upon it.  the night before i couldn't wait and got some fishnchips at another pub and they were DISGUSTING.  It's so worth the wait to take the time to find this place.it looks like a hole-in-the-wall kind of place, not that impressive at all when you first approach it.  it took a while for our food to come but it was so delicious.  we got Haddock and Halibut.  The Halibut was supreme, although i doubt i've ever had bad halibut.  we got some mushy peas just because i was told i had to (by the Brit i met in the first place) and they weren't that bad (i hate peas).  My only complaint is the fries or 'chips', they were not to my tastes, i like crispy and moist fries, these were kinda dried out and mushy, but the fish makes up for it.  go during the day so you can sit on the street level, we went to check it out the night before and it was packed, and you don't want to sit downstairs.overall, i'm SO glad this place was recommended to me cuz otherwise i would have just had the terrible fish and chips experience from the night before.  go check it out when you are in London!

BU2tz2fdlFncYwaxK399xQ.text: Your go-to Fish and Chips place. It's delicious - though seating can be a bit awkward downstairs and it's a bit overpriced. Every time my mates and I had a fish and chips craving we went here.  Would recommend to anyone.

7jopxKW9om4Qi63uyTqOUQ.text: this place was pretty good....  basically there were 4 of us, and we split 2 orders... one with chips and one individual... and for pretty reasonable as well.. I think less than 15L if I remember correctly.In, out, fast, friendly staff, nothing to complain about other than the fact that we had it as take-away and there was no where for us to sit and eat nearby(our own fault really).

HUYNJwznXjXIyERDaauzlw.text: To add to the list of puns, whilst this place isn't exactly as cheap as chips, what you do get is well worth the money and definitely worth a return trip. A takeaway will cut about £3 off the price of your meal, but you'll need to find somewhere in the surrounding area to eat your meal, which isn't necessarily the easiest thing to do. If you're eating in, there are a few tables inside and plenty more outside, but be prepared to wait if you're turning up when the place is busy at the weekends. Definitely recommended.

tE2emMBMJgXKRyOA6Eofzg.text: The concierge at our hotel recommended  Rock & Sole Plaice as one of the better spots to have fish and chips while visiting London - she was right.Both my friend and I had the cod, which was crispy and flavorful, but did not overpower the natural flavor of the fish. Be sure to try this restaurant when in London; we had a great time sitting on their patio with a beer and out lunch - a great pit stop before continuing on with your day.

eNQVrI9eXQxoKJMJK7Nu2w.text: I am soooo disappointed. This place used to be one of the best chippies in London. They were voted in the top 10 in the UK and were very proud of that ..this was 5-6 years ago. The service used to be fab, they communicated if there was going to be a wait and the food was always awesome... What Happened? We visited here last night and after a truly crappy service didn't even end up eating. So what happened ? We we were on our way to see the Editors in Brixton. We thought the perfect way to prepare ourselves for lots of Brixton lager was to fill our bellies with delicious fish or sausage and batter and chips ( I don't eat fish...). so we rocked up ..decided to eat in and waited ... and waited ..we were then served , one rock and chips and 2 sausage in batter and chips with extra beans ..mmmmmmmmmm yums!  The place was in a certain degree of chaos which should have been a warning sign. so anyways .. we waited ...... and waited ... the queue of take away was been served immediately ...they were getting there food straight away and wandering off to enjoy .... we were left ... the take away purchasers kept coming and walking away with their hands full. By this time it was getting late .. we were close to missing the editors if we had to wait much longer. I politely asked the waitress ( not a smile in sight) how much longer it might be as we had already let them know when we sat down that we needed to be somewhere and were assured that it would be a quick service. She responded with 'its coming now' ..so we waited ...and waited a bit longer ....still the take aways being handed out .... other people in the cafe being served ..not us ... so I asked again ...only to hear her declare to the kitchen people that table 1 was complaining .. i wasn't even complaining .. just asking as she had told me it was coming now 10 minutes ago .... so a place of cod and chips was put in front of me ...hmmm i'm sorry ,i think this is not for us .. we ordered one rock and chips and 2 sausage and chips .. so the guy huffed and took it away ..coming back to let us know that the Rock was taking a bit longer as was fresh ... he said he could bring the sausage over anyway ..lovely we thought ..starving by this point and rather late! ....So he reappeared with one sausage in batter and chips with a bit of very greasy battered fish dumped on the top ...' you can have the fish for free as you have been waiting so long he declared' .... Im sorry but as someone who doesn't like fish, someone who was hungry and fed up with the way that we had been treated so far ..that did it. 'im sorry' i replied, 'but I dont eat fish' he went ahead and removed the fish from my plate with his fingers ...touching my chips in process ..leaving a lovely pool of grease on the plate and put it back in the cabinate ... that did it .. we needed to remove ourselves from the situation so left.Now there are a couple of things to say ... if this was a chippy that was selling fish and chips for  5 quid, i probably would have let it go ... but these guys charge 10 to eat in ... in my book that is an expensive fish and chips and expect some sort of service, even if its just to be notified when i order that Rock takes longer to cook .. not to be told when I sit down that they would be able to do our order quickly.\I will never go back here. Neither will the people I was with. Really disappointed as they used to be so good and I was so looking forward to some scrummy sausage in batter and chips ....

EI4-zATmmhroBRZrd5e9Cg.text: On my parents last night in London my dad really wanted Fish and Chips and after reading timeout's and some yelp reviews we decided on Rock and Sole.  Their outdoor area was just a few picnic tables set up on the street not very picturesque but it was a beautiful night so we waited for an outdoor table.  The food was OK, nothing special, and they had a limited beer menu, 2 choices to be exact. Yet, the service was good and so was the location, only a few blocks away from Covent Garden.

QiQ9XF9FXWuRiUEyIVY46g.text: This was the first place i tried when I got in. Love the neighbor and was window shopping and was excited to eat and go shopping after. The fish was cooked to perfection and good chips. You have to try the sticky toffee here, it came hot and was perfect is a cool afternoon. It is touristy but you see the local usually doing take out during lunch.

2kC4rh8be-FqJhqtvECQEQ.text: I believe I may be the only 2-star review for this place, but I was really disappointed in the food here. In fact, 'Meh' implies a certain level of indifference in my book and I feel almost more strongly that the fish and chips here were Bleeeaaarrrgh. That's a very scientific bit of terminology by the way. Why? First off, the fish and chips were £10 at minimum with table seating, twice as much as takeaway. That seems wholly overpriced for what is essentially a huge plate of greasy breaded randomness. I wasn't really that hungry so I got the fish cake for £4.50 and it resembled a dry deep-fried hockey puck. Chips were soft and kind of mealy rather than crispy and flavorful. The outside seating is nice but the inside just doesn't seem that clean. Now I fully admit that I didn't try the fish and maybe it's so orgasmic that it overrides all the other negatives. But there is so much better food in general and in the vicinity, that you can get for half the price. And in terms of my fish and chips experience, even a posh place like Canteen has fish and chips for about the same price if not cheaper and they do a really good crunchy breadcrumb shell rather than an oily battered crust. I realize this may be fish-and-chips blasphemy, but it seems like an overpriced tourist trap without the chops (chips?) to back it up.

Ft43cJ-6M9BEJfNiYwfH2Q.text: our local friends suggested "hey, you're here in England, might as well get fish and chips" and brought us here.works for me.  we sat outside, at a table for 6, and of course all of us gorged on our share of fish and chips.  the fish was not dry, and the batter was a nice golden color, and just the right amount of crispiness without being over-fried.  the chips were dont satisfactorily, but i would have wanted them done a little more well-done for an added crunch - but perhaps that's just personal preference.nonetheless, i'd come back.

4yfS3VcU61ehgKBtQdyOgA.text: For many moons I have sauntered past 'Rock and Sole Plaice' and longingly gazed at the battered wonders that graced the diner's plates. Finally the opportunity arose and £11 worth of cod and chips with mushy peas was heading my way. Sat outdoors enjoying the exhaust fumes, it was somehow less glamorous that I had imagined but the atmosphere still ensued. The food arrived and I dove in, drooling on myself at the massive feast that lay ahead. It was hot and oh so tasty!Clearly not-a-one-of-you has had the experience of visiting the lou in this establishment. It is beyond shocking, comparable to Porta-Lous at overcrowded festivals and utterly sub-standard. The basement seating area reeks of must, the bathroom floors are soaking wet and mould is encroaching on every surface. I got back to my table and had a hard time finishing my meal. The food is by far 5* but the dreadful toilets are 0*'s in my book. It is a really unfortunate flaw in an otherwise amazing restaurant.

p85N7CPYq1TR5vJUajW0cA.text: I had fish & chips there once too, it's great!The seats outside are lovely if you can withstand the cold. Inside is ok too, but the air does get a bit greasy.Highly recommended plaice (haha) if you're looking for the Great British Fish & Chip experience :)

Ga3YcGTitOP4RhxoOCqA0g.text: Really good fish and chips in London are hard to come by, and 9 times out of 10 they are found by recommendation. Rock and Sole Plaice, on Endell Street is one of the best places for Fish and Chips. Their fish is fresh and tasty, and their chips are generous in size and portion. On a friday afternoon, the queue will spill out onto the street. I would advise getting a take away though. There are three seating areas: on the ground floor, in the basement, and on the street. On the street is fine if it's a lovely day, and you don't mind the fumes from the Endell Street car traffic (which seems to be getting busier by the day), but the only place I wouldn't recommend is sitting downstairs. It's very close to the hygiene facilities and occasionally the smell can be overpowering to the point of distraction. If fish isn't the way you roll, they also serve chicken, battered sausage and a variety of other chippie-related foods. It's all a bit heart-stoppingly cholesterol driven, but you really REALLY should treat yourself. This is a chippie at it's best, and is always hit, never miss, and they've managed to keep the quality up.

Jb1JB5cAlxlYhSpS9Tt1rA.text: Whenever I have a craving for fish and chips, this place always seems to satisfy. Located one street away from the main hustle and bustle of Covent Garden, the Rock & Sole Plaice is sometimes quite easy to miss although given the number of diners that always seems to be there, never seems to have a problem filling it up. Even though most people like to sit outside during the summer months, I only recently found out they have a much larger dining room downstairs, perfect for when it's drizzling outside. At the end of the day, it is just a fish and chip store, though what it does, it does really well.

KgZ5cbsQTuuDE6rfCNHlQg.text: Great fish in a cozy environment. I tried their Skate fish and it was very tasty!

-IEysqod-MofcQFCgibS8g.text: Not a great fan of fish&chips but this was so far the best I had in London! Plus it's on a very lovely street, which gives a Mediterranean feeling. Enjoy your fish&chips and beer and relax...

dH6LREhy_tDHYUDHlWeFjg.text: Great old school fish and chips. A bit expensive - I'm not sure if that's due to the marquee name or the location - but overall very good. Simple, no fuss, Fish & Chips

sGFa1fOqS5m8Y0rM25rEvA.text: My first trip to London was last November, and one of my MUST DO's included finding a good fish & chip shop.  This one was highly recommended (think by Lonely Planet) and I was NOT disappointed! There was SO much I couldn't even finish half, which saddened me terribly Fish was crisp outside, soft and lovely on the inside, chips the same.  I'd go back again in a heartbeat (and likely will, given I'm headed back to London shortly!!).

eCA5SuKBW_eDbNccnUU7JA.text: This is a great place to stop off during a shopping spree in Covent Garden. It's a bit more down to earth (and therefore cheaper) that the restaurants actually around Covent Garden piazza and is a brilliant example of British cuisine at its best! I used to work round the corner from here and it was all too easy to drop in after a bad day at the office for something yummy to cheer myself up. The delicious smells draw you in as you walk past and it's hard to resist. I like it best in summer when you can sit outside under the fairy lights in the evening and enjoy your fish and chips in the open air. However, there's a dining room downstairs (that I only discovered was there after I'd been to The Rock & Sole Plaice half-a-dozen times) which means you can eat comfortably in the winter or if it's raining. You do come away with your clothes smelling of frying though, so don't wear anything that'll need dry cleaning! Really fresh fish in crispy batter with golden chips - nothing can beat it - and this is just the place to come and find it.

8xnKDMy4g62ZDVEcd4BUGw.text: This place was definitely the dog's bollocks! My first and only fish and chips experience in London couldn't have been better. I ordered the haddock and it was just a flaky, fresh and tasty as the menu had described.  My friend who got the cod was not as impressed- actually, he ordered rockfish, but got cod. It took a while for our food to come out, but at least it was good. The chips were tasty as well. I wouldn't recommend dining outside though, those damn pigeons were all over the place- we were outside at first, but one of the birds pooped on a friend's menu, so we took it indoors. The prices were decent, the beer was cold and the staff was competent. I would definitely recommend Rock & Sole for an authentic fish and chips experience if you're ever in the neighborhood- and there's great shopping in the area as well.

5bDmD6DReO6Qr9q5beU-Bw.text: This is allegedly the oldest (and in my opinion best) fish-and-chip shop in London. I grew up just around the corner from here in Covent Garden and often came here after school. The smell from down the road of salt and vinegar still makes me grin with happiness like nothing else. The fish here is cooked superbly, with a large range of varieties of fish always being sold, along with other chip-shop food. Even if you don't want fish, the chips are still great, proper good chips, with large generous portions. You haven't tried fish and chips until you have tried them here.

UDtA3wHHZ1wsUacW11JQ0w.text: this is my one and only fish and chips experience so take my review how you will. if i ever came back her, i would skip the mushy peas as well as the chicken and mushroom pie. i would also do take out since its cheaper and faster. fish is nice big size. lots of chips. tartar sauce is excellent.

90eMajafSGIA3qUvqQIDLw.text: We were seated right away at the outside benches. Kate ordered the Cod, I ordered the Haddock (from what I remember). The portions were nice size. They had a nice'n'crispy battered coating;  the inside was moist and flaky. The chips were good. The service was good. We liked the Rock & Sole Plaice.

Photo of Rock & Sole Plaice - London, United Kingdom

urH-gmLfAD3OA2hCYBTt2A.text: Outdoor seating, indoor main level seating and downstairs seating available. This restaurant has history for its fish n chips! It been around for over 100 years.We sat downstairs, ordered the large cod and large haddock. They have regular for £15 and large for £18. Made to order and still piping hot when it's brought out and served to you. Service is prompt, no frills. Pay at the till on the way out. Good location near covent garden.Will be back if craving fish and chips!

eCOTJVIaV8MhzarLQxh6lg.text: So as an America visiting London I figured I had to grab some fish and chips! In America we just give little pieces of Cod so I was totally not expecting to get the whole freaking fillet! The staff was nice, service was fast and the food was good!

photos.caption: Photo of Rock & Sole Plaice - London, United Kingdom. Large size Cod and chips!

YKGO6m8WTKSK_QrBQKj63g.text: This chippie is rather pricey for non-fancy fare but it is in Convent Garden, so I suppose it's to be expected. I thought the fish (cod or haddock) and chips were nicely done - quite filling. Tartare sauce was also great. But I did NOT like the mushy peas!! They were vile so I suggest skipping the mushy peas. I'm speaking as a non-mushy peas lover.

RvpriEcIbS9lp9gmnDjw_Q.text: The reason I'm giving a five star is relative to what I have expected from a traditional fish and chips place being told by my friends. The cod fish meat was spongy and chewy. Would like to try the chicken nugget the next time.

photos.caption: Photo of Rock & Sole Plaice - London, United Kingdom

aKYxiR7xSfaSQWdFnm6Bxw.text: Fish and chips were very good. Nice flaky cod with crunchy batter that was properly cooked and not too greasy. Setting was classic. Nothing fancy inside. A bit warm. The curry sauce was our favorite.  The calamari was forgettable. We liked it. But we won't rush back before trying some other spots.

JEAjOLQC2jd6OnhyuqeIig.text: 5 years since our last encounter, R&SP and I meet once again. Perhaps we have both grown apart, but I felt slightly dissatisfied after this time around.The place still looks like as I have remembered it: no frills/fast service, basic tables/tableware, and a simple menu. We got the regular cod again. The batter remained too crispy and the fish tender as I remembered it. The chips were fine, nothing to complain about, just as I remembered it.  However, I don't remember the mushy peas being bland, and I felt this time I didn't enjoy the peas so much. Also, I don't remember the price being so high for such a moderate portion.Perhaps we might meet again; perhaps we might not.

duySrR9nVAWfNLvv3pLJAA.text: This venerable place was actually founded at its present location in 1871, and its basement room served as a meeting place for community volunteers to plan where provisions would be distributed throughout London to displaced persons during the Blitz while WW II still raged on.  So, besides being a fine purveyor of seafood and chips, it has some historical significance.Since being in London is an infrequent treat, I ordered a wide array of culinary offerings.  Onion Rings with a batter like cornmeal were very good, as was homemade creamy Coleslaw.  Pieces of deep-fried crunchy Calamari looked unusual in a shape like a ring and tasted like a yielding band within the better.  A huge portion of Plaice, with excellent crunchy batter, was delicate, but the fish was a little mushy, just as some of the deep-fried cod was undercooked but still satisfying.  It got better after the first few bites, and was enhanced by Malt Vinegar and an excellent creamy housemade Tartar Sauce.  Diane didn't like that a layer of skin was still on her cod, but this was easily removed.  Chips were thick, good, and interesting.  Warm Toffee Pudding with Vanilla Custard was a nice sweet treat to close the meal.Seating is rather austere, and we had to share an outdoor table.  But it was a pleasant day, and service was prompt and efficient.XXXX overall on my one outing!

OytTxdD03CegtfxcR4em8Q.text: There's seating inside (which is quite squashed), outside (with traffic) and further seating in the basement. Gets very busy being on the outskirt of Covent Garden, lots of tourists.The cod and handful of chips, and a small portion of mushy peas was quite pricey, since the batter was quite thick to make the fish look like a large portion.  However, the chips were proper fat chips, nice and hot and crunchy outside and soft inside, the saveloy was good too!  And a really decent hot chocolate, not lukewarm and watery, can taste the chocolate!(Visited on a rainy Saturday,10 May 2014)

1CIGVcFaJpCYQ1-ZC7Z7tQ.text: We came here because we wanted to try excellent fish and chips.  What we got was good, but nothing to get overly excited about.  We started with calamari.  We didn't enjoy it because it was really thick circles that made it chewy...it was too greasy to be crispy.  The fish itself was good...we got the cod.  I also got a Czech beer, which was interesting and seemed a bit out of place.  My daughter got the fried chicken strips and thought they were ok.  The breading was different than the fish...not as light.  The service was quick and good.  Overall, it served it's purpose and we didn't regret the stop, but we wouldn't go out of our way to go there again.

KhcjHFcV9TxU_Rfn_Ms71A.text: No pictures, because I was in London earlier this year and wasn't an enthusiastic Yelper as I am now. Anyway, I found this place online before leaving for my trip and I couldn't wait to try the fish and chips. We walked and walked and walked for what seemed hours in very cold elements to find this little restaurant, which I just knew would have tremendous fish and chips, since it lauded itself as being the first fish and chips restaurant in London. I thought they were tasty but II've had just as good fish and chips at local pubs throughout London. I loved the really yummy palate pleasing hot tea! I wonder what brand it was? Yummy!

EO9034tWz17KiMZN9O5iEA.text: The fish (cod) and chips are really good. Perfectly battered and fried. Not super greasy and doesn't make you feel ick after finishing. The only reason why I didn't go for a 4 star is because it really is overpriced- the large is a good size, so I recommend sharing the large with someone. Good for visitors (very touristy) to get a good taste of fish & chips (at the high price). It's a small place so not good to go with too big of a group during busy time.

photos.caption: Photo of Rock & Sole Plaice - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Rock & Sole Plaice - London, United Kingdom. Large portion Cod & Chips

qskbv0FrVhepebrh0Bv-yw.text: This was close to our hotel, and the food was fine, but we had a lot better food at other places. Good for sitting outdoors and having a drink.

j0C95EazcOm3ee7hTyzcIQ.text: Had fish and chips and a beer here for dinner. My wife and I split a large order or cod fish and chips. It was plenty of food for two people. The batter on the fish was super crunchy, but the fish was a little soggy and kept falling apart. It was hard to get a bit to your mouth without some of it falling off your fork. The chips were good, but could have been crispier. The seating was comfortable and the service was great. Overall a nice place to grab a meal.

photos.caption: Photo of Rock & Sole Plaice - London, United Kingdom. Easy to spot, right on the corner.

UTaeXCTMeXa5dDSZ4Vqxcw.text: I'm not too sure if our visit was a fluke but I must contest all of the 4 and 5 star ratings for this place. The GF finally made it to the UK and wanted to try a  proper fish and chips. Being that we were in Covet Gardens this place shined as the place to go for fish and chips in the area. I mean this place has been around for over a 100 years so it must be good right?!? That's what I thought... Having a recently found fancy for haddock I ordered a large haddock and chips and beef and onion pie for us to share.The fish and chips was served at room temperature like it had been sitting out for a while or they gave us someones take away order... You could tell because the meat was already dry and the chips were soggy and clammy. I wanted to send the order back but the waitress was nowhere to be found and by the time I would've got a hold of her it would've been worse. After breaking into the fish I noticed the skin was left on. I don't know if this is a sign of laziness or how it is traditionally served since the other 2 places ( The Pheasant and Kerbisher & Malt) that I have fish and chips earlier in the trip had the skin removed. The obviously takes away from being able to enjoy a complete through and through crunch of the fish because you have to cut and slide the fish off the skin. I know it seems trivial but it really does kill the texture of the dish. As I mentioned previously the chips were rubbish. They were cold, clammy and barely edible. I don't know if the staff thought they could pile crap on our plate because we were tourists or they were lazy and served us leftovers. The beef and onion pie was very underwhelming and like the fish and ships was served at room temp and not piping hot. The fries that accompanied the pie suffered the same problem that the other dish did. Cold and clammy chips... What a fail....  If this is how they do business how have they managed to stay in business for so long? Needless to say I would not recommend this to be your place to blow your load on fish and chips on your London trip. Like most people, these 2 dishes were on my must eat list while in London and like everyone else on holiday we must make the most out of where we eat. So getting a bust of a joint like this place ruins your holiday experience.  Tourist tip:Take the underground to Hammersmith and go to Kerbisher & Malt. The locals say its a posh joint but costs just as much as a tourist trap like this place. You wont be disappointed. I like to end on a positive note so here it is: They gave us a free postcard for our travels.

photos.caption: Photo of Rock & Sole Plaice - London, United Kingdom. Beef and onion pie with chips
Photo of Rock & Sole Plaice - London, United Kingdom. Large haddock and mushy peas

I3wCcyIkoFaK2R3pFKDYww.text: I am really shocked by this place and honestly maybe the five star reviews is because I never really liked Fish & Chips, or I've only had terrible Fish & Chips, either way this place was mind-blowingly good. I had this spot on my radar for London frankly because it was probably one of the most reviewed places. I was definitely skeptical, as I mentioned above, as I am not the biggest fried foods fan, and I was afraid that it was going to be way too touristy or just kind of a sell out. I also do remember fish and chips from freezers long ago as well as ... places here in the US claiming to have "fish & chips." We got in line to order, and actually it wasn't too busy, and we got to sit inside on this slightly overcast day. The service was pleasant, and the food came quickly. MY GOODNESS. Was it fresh. Wow! I have never had such a deliciously tender and flavorful fried fish. It was juicy, moist, everything I didn't think fish could be, especially when cooked. The batter was not heavy, greasy or in anyway intrusive to the flavor. It actually added a nice texture to the fish. Plus, the chunk that we received was huge, it was like half of the plate! I was really surprised, shocked, both pleasantly, by this place and I have to say that it really has been the best Fish & Chips I have **ever** had and I would not hesitate to recommend it or to go back again. YUMMM

VrV9lh-QDEiIxuB1G-gO-A.text: Came here on a Sunday evening after the British Museum is closed.   The place is not full and we shared an outdoor bench with another person.   Ordering food was quick and easy.    We ordered one with cod and one with haddock.  Strangely, the food took a while to come but the fish was fresh, huge, piping hot and the chips were excellent.  We are definitely not fish &  chips expert but we definitely enjoy the local British flavor.

DmvKU5DgzGsLbHdBPNUksQ.text: When one goes to London, one must have fish and chips. I mean. If one wants to be touristy!And we were tourists. So we trekked to Rock and Sole Plaice (play on words w. some delicious white fish). They have outdoor seating which must be nice when it's not raining (wait, when does it NOT rain?!), they have indoor seating at street level and apparently they have more seating downstairs which you go outside to go down (we did not see this part so have no idea what it looks like).If you're doing takeout you'll pay less. If you're staying, you'll pay more and no this apparently does not include tip (did not know this. so sorry...we're not cheap bast*ds...really!).Service is so-so and im giving it 4 stars for the fish.  Really awesome fish.  Lightly battered, fried crisp and the fish itself is moist, fresh and DELICIOUS.  The chips were eh. We're not fan of fat fries...But they were fresh potato and you could taste it.Where we sat we were surrounded by musical and theatre flyers and behind those is white tile quite reminiscent of a bath...Otherwise we were quite happy sitting down even if it was a little cramped.Great suggestion by one of our friends, it was worth wandering the streets starving just to find it :)

26I_2BiCFVkVXMsV6VvsTg.text: What's more convenient fun than spending time with Yelp friends exploring their city on holiday? The answer is spending time with visiting Yelp friends exploring your own city!My good Yelp friend Lorrie M contacted me a few months ago when she was planning a trip to London and we arranged to hang out when she was in town. It's always fascinating to see your own city through the eyes of someone from outside, who may perhaps have different insights from your own jaded local's viewpoint.In amongst Lorrie's challenging 3 day schedule to see virtually all the big sights and many Yelp recommended local experiences was to have good ol' British fish and chipsRock & Sole Plaice is in fact about 15 steps from one of my regular gelato haunts, Scoop in Covent Garden but I've never been aware that this was here and therefore never considered eating here for lunch. Branded a tourist haunt by locals and therefore probably avoided for that reason, I was intrigued to find that this restaurant actually has a long history going back to 1871, being the 3rd chippy ever in London, long before mass tourism became popularWe managed to snag a table to ourselves indoors though I can see that you might have to share tables at busy times. Prices reflect its prime Covent Garden location though I think portions are generous - our normal sized fillets of fish were plenty for usOur deep fried cod and rock were covered in a wonderfully crispy batter, which broke open to reveal moist, flaky fish. They have definitely got the fish frying down to a tee after 141 years! Who cares if this is a tourist haunt if they can cook this quintessential British dish like this?The chips were traditional chippy chips - broad with crusty edges and floury insides and best eaten warm while they're still crisp. The only disappointment was the mushy peas which tasted unpleasantly chalky for some reason and could have done with some sweetnessThanks for Lorrie M for introducing me to a delight in my own city and so close to Scoop, where we popped into for some dessert!

lK9AXEufs--miCs50NZSoA.text: Recommended to us for fish and chips so we gave it a shot. Seemed like a typical fast food/fried food place. I had chicken and chips, my sister had fish and chips. It was pricy but the portions were big so we left full. Ok service. Our food came out later than people who had walked in after and ordered after us.

MdCrp8mYBzwpZ3QLrvRimA.text: Tonight, I'm a world away, eating a flaky, white fish fried up by my Gram in our little kitchen...but I'm reminiscing of eating fish and chips on the streets of London at Rock & Sole.  My dad chose it because of reviews, so it seemed fitting that I threw in my own 2 cents (or pence?).  All that we had was good but I'm not a fish connoisseur.  What I do know is that I liked my cheaper haddock more than my dad's more expensive halibut.  Was it the best fish and chips we had? No...but we're tourists and this was the first place I felt I got a taste of "British flavor"...London seemed so diverse to me, that this fit what I was looking for as we got better acquainted with the city. (Well, we ate outside at the patio tables...nothing about the downstairs decor or the ladies room toilets with plastic "sea things" in the seat said British to me!! But I know I'm not reviewing the loo.) At any rate, I have fond memories of this Plaice!  It looks like I'm not the only one...
